title: Getting Started with lme4u
text: Hierarchical (mixed-effects) models essential tools analyzing data grouped nested structure — think students within schools patients within hospitals. comes fitting models R, lme4 package go-hub. lme4 offers incredible modeling features, can also hard wrap head around. Many users — especially transitioning stats::lm() lme4::lmer() even lme4::glmer() — find overwhelmed jump complexity: random intercepts slopes, link-scale estimates, nested structures, . ’s lme4u comes play. Built directly top lme4, package designed help interpret, diagnose, hypothesis-test mixed models clarity confidence. Whether ’re student learning mixed models first time researcher working real-world grouped data, lme4u walks process practical explanations inspiring tools.

title: Getting Started with lme4u
text: lme4u comes built-dataset, star, cleaned subset well-known Project STAR (student-teacher achievement ratio) data. original dataset follows students across elementary school years Tennessee, aiming study effect class size student test performance. processed version lme4u focuses student performance third grade, ensuring hierarchical structure students nested within schools. shape star 4192 * 13, includes subset key variables related student demographics, prior-year (2nd grade) current-year (3rd grade) test scores, class assignment, teacher qualifications, school-level identifiers. students dataset controlled attending school 2nd 3rd grades. view details data dictionary, run ?star loading lme4u workspace.

title: Getting Started with lme4u
text: context star, suppose ’re intersted understanding: class type affect student math performance, accounting prior achievements? relationship vary across schools? type question common education research, students grouped within schools, individual- group-level heterogeneity contribute outcomes. R using lme4, implemented : course, ways modeling relation. use specific model demonstrate lme4u makes interpretation diagnostics easier throughout vignette.
code: model <- lmer(math ~ cltype + math_old + (cltype | school_id), data = star)

title: Getting Started with lme4u
text: Immediately model fit, might start wondering whether model structure appropriate, simply, formula means statistically. core component package, explain_lmer(), provides structured, user-friendly interpretations linear mixed effects models fitted using lme4::lmer(). function designed bridge gap raw model output intuitive understanding, making easier users interpret model structure results.

title: Getting Started with lme4u
text: explain_lmer() supports three levels interpretation via details argument. default, "general" run argument supplied details, provides high-level summary model, describing structure, fixed effects, random effects concise yet informative manner:
code: explain_lmer(model) #> This linear mixed-effects model examines how cltype, math_old affects math, while accounting for group-level variability across school_id. #>  #> The model adjusts for fixed effect(s), including cltype, math_old, which estimate the overall relationship with math across the entire dataset. For more detailed interpretations of fixed effects, use `details = "fixed"`. #>  #> The model includes the following random effects across grouping variables: cltype | school_id. #>  *The random intercept(s), school_id, account for variations in the intercept across different groups, allowing each group to have its own baseline value that deviates from the overall average. #>  *On top of the varying baselines, the model allows the effects of cltype on math to differ across their corresponding groups. This means that not only can each group start from a different baseline, but the strength and direction of the relationships between these variables and math can also vary from one group to another. #> Check `details = 'random'` for more interpretation.

title: Getting Started with lme4u
text: "fixed" input, function offers detailed explanation fixed effects, including interpretations individual estimates implications within model context: NOTE: interaction fitted model, function also able detect adjust interpretation.
code: fix <- explain_lmer(model, details = "fixed") #> This model includes the following fixed effects: cltypesmall, cltyperegular+aide, math_old, along with the baseline estimate (Intercept). #> Fixed effects estimate the average relationship between the predictors and the response variable `math` across all groups. #> These effects reflect how changes in each predictor influence `math`, assuming all other variables are held constant and deviations from the baseline are measured accordingly. #>  #> To interpret the estimates: #> - The <Estimate> represents the expected change in `math` for a one-unit change in the predictor.  #> - The <Standard Error> reflects uncertainty around the estimate. #> - The <t-value> measures the significance of the effect relative to its variability. #> - The <Correlation> provides insight into the relationships between fixed effect predictors. #>  #>  #> For detailed interpretations of each fixed effect, use: `attr(, 'fixed_details')[['variable_name']]` to view specific results. You can find the list of available fixed effect variable names using: `attr(, 'fixed_names')` to guide your extraction. attr(fix, "fixed_details") #> $`(Intercept)` #> [1] "The intercept estimate suggests that when all predictors are set to zero, the expected value of `math` is approximately 201.646. This serves as the baseline for evaluating the effects of other variables in the model." #>  #> $cltypesmall #> [1] "The fixed effect for 'cltypesmall' suggests that for a one-unit increase in 'cltypesmall', the expected change in `math` is approximately -0.434, assuming all other variables are held constant. This estimate has a standard error of 2.406 and a t-value of -0.18. To assess the overall impact of this effect, consider it relative to the model's baseline intercept." #>  #> $`cltyperegular+aide` #> [1] "The fixed effect for 'cltyperegular+aide' suggests that for a one-unit increase in 'cltyperegular+aide', the expected change in `math` is approximately -0.117, assuming all other variables are held constant. This estimate has a standard error of 2.503 and a t-value of -0.047. To assess the overall impact of this effect, consider it relative to the model's baseline intercept." #>  #> $math_old #> [1] "The fixed effect for 'math_old' suggests that for a one-unit increase in 'math_old', the expected change in `math` is approximately 0.715, assuming all other variables are held constant. This estimate has a standard error of 0.01 and a t-value of 69.735. To assess the overall impact of this effect, consider it relative to the model's baseline intercept."

title: Getting Started with lme4u
text: "random" input, function focuses random effects, explaining random intercepts, slopes, variance components highlight across-group variability: NOTE: random part also capable detecting nested grouping structure, uncorrelated random effects, multi-level random structures. However, use interpretation deliberately complex cases.
code: random <- explain_lmer(model, details = "random") #> There is 1 random term you fit in the model: #>  #> cltype | school_id: Your model assumes there is across-group heterogeneity in the baseline level of math across school_id (random intercepts), allowing each group to have its own starting point that deviates from the overall average. Additionally, the effects of cltype on math are allowed to vary within each school_id (random slopes), capturing differences in these relationships across groups. #>  #> To explore variance contributions based on the model estimates, use: `attr(, 'var_details')`. attr(random, "var_details") #> $high_var #> [1] "The following terms explain a substantial proportion of the variance: Residual. This suggests that these random effects contribute meaningfully to capturing group-level heterogeneity. Note: The residual variance dominates, suggesting that within-group heterogeneity explains most of the variation. This could indicate a weak random effect structure." #>  #> $low_var #> [1] "The following terms explain a relatively small portion of the variance: NA, school_id - (Intercept). You might reconsider including these terms in your random effect structure if their contributions are negligible."

title: Getting Started with lme4u
text: (TBD)

title: Getting Started with lme4u
text: ’ve interpreted model checked assumptions reasonably hold, next natural step test whether certain effects — fixed random — meaningfully contribute model. lrt_lmer() provides likelihood ratio tests selected fixed random effect fitted lme4::lmer() model. aims gauge effect brought one single term apply statistically accurate null distribution based different effect types. Depending whether ’re testing fixed effect random effect type argument, structure reduced model differs. Currently, function supports lmer models fixed effects single random structure (.e., nested /, double vertical ||, multi-level random effects). see testing logic reduced models constructed differently, run ?lrt_lmer.

title: Getting Started with lme4u
text: test whether selected fixed effect exists, specify exact variable name target set type = "fixed". allow function match underlying set fixed terms. Running function give summary output, along test statistics returned list: NOTE: interaction fitted model, specify has_interaction = TRUE input argument. reduced model subsequently constructed without selected fixed effect interaction terms containing .
code: fix_result <- lrt_lmer(model, target = "math_old", type = "fixed", data = star) #> Likelihood Ratio Test for 'math_old' (fixed effect) #> Full Model: math ~ cltype + math_old + (cltype | school_id) #> Reduced Model: math ~ cltype + (cltype | school_id) #> Test Statistics: #> - Log-Likelihood Difference: 3202.807 #> - Degrees of Freedom: 1 (Difference in estimated parameters) #> - P-Value: < 2.2e-16 (Chi-square test) #> Since p = < 2.2e-16, under alpha level of 0.05, we reject the null hypothesis. The test suggests that the fixed effect of math_old is statistically significant and contributes to the model. fix_result #> $logLik #> [1] 3202.807 #>  #> $df #> [1] 1 #>  #> $pvalue #> [1] 0

title: Getting Started with lme4u
text: test excess heterogeneity contributed random effect term, specify exact variable name target set type = "random". , function check whether target random intercept (grouping variable) random slope model, apply corresponding computation likelihood ratio test. Random Intercept: full model reconstructed modifying original lme4::lmer() call retain random intercept (ignoring random slopes). reduced model standard stats::lm() model containing fixed effects, likelihood ratio test follows mixture Chi-square distribution p-value computation. Random Slope: target variable removed random slope structure. reduced model remains lme4::lmer() model, likelihood ratio test follows mixture Chi-square distribution p-value computation.
code: random_result1 <- lrt_lmer(model, target = "school_id", type = "random", data = star) #> Likelihood Ratio Test for 'school_id' (random intercept effect) #> Full Model: math ~ cltype + math_old + (1 | school_id) #> Reduced Model: math ~ cltype + math_old #> Test Statistics: #> - Log-Likelihood Difference: 603.7954 #> - Degrees of Freedom: 1 (Difference in estimated parameters) #> - P-Value: < 2.2e-16 (Chi-square test) #> Since p = < 2.2e-16, under alpha level of 0.05, we reject the null hypothesis. The test suggests that the random intercept effect of school_id is statistically significant and contributes to the model. random_result2 <- lrt_lmer(model, target = "cltype", type = "random", data = star) #> Likelihood Ratio Test for 'cltype' (random slope effect) #> Full Model: math ~ cltype + math_old + (cltype | school_id) #> Reduced Model: math ~ cltype + math_old + (1 | school_id) #> Test Statistics: #> - Log-Likelihood Difference: 326.1249 #> - Degrees of Freedom: 5 (Difference in estimated parameters) #> - P-Value: < 2.2e-16 (Chi-square test) #> Since p = < 2.2e-16, under alpha level of 0.05, we reject the null hypothesis. The test suggests that the random slope effect of cltype is statistically significant and contributes to the model.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Holly Cui. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Cui H (2025). lme4u: Interpretation Diagnostics 'lme4' Hierarchical Models. R package version 0.1.0.9000, https://hollyyfc.github.io/lme4u/, https://github.com/hollyyfc/lme4u.
code: @Manual{,   title = {lme4u: Interpretation and Diagnostics for 'lme4' Hierarchical Models},   author = {Holly Cui},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.0.9000, https://hollyyfc.github.io/lme4u/},   url = {https://github.com/hollyyfc/lme4u}, }

title: Interpretation and Diagnostics for lme4 Hierarchical Models
text: lme4u interpretation diagnostic tool linear mixed-effects models fitted lme4 package. aims provide: Interpretive functions translate lmer() output user-friendly explanations. Diagnostic tools checking model assumptions visualizing hierarchical structures. Hypothesis testing utilities facilitate model comparison statistical inference. Curated data purpose exploring mixed-effect models.

title: Interpretation and Diagnostics for lme4 Hierarchical Models
text: can install development version lme4u GitHub :
code: devtools::install_github("hollyyfc/lme4u")  # Alternatively: # install.packages("pak") pak::pak("hollyyfc/lme4u")

title: Interpretation and Diagnostics for lme4 Hierarchical Models
text: lme4u built assist lme4 modeling, make sure packages properly loaded:
code: library(lme4u) library(lme4)

title: Interpretation and Diagnostics for lme4 Hierarchical Models
text: core interpretation function provides user-friendly explanation fitted lmer model’s fixed random effects:
code: model <- lme4::lmer(math ~ cltype + math_old + (cltype | school_id), data = star)  explain_lmer(model, details = "general") #> This linear mixed-effects model examines how cltype, math_old affects math, while accounting for group-level variability across school_id. #>  #> The model adjusts for fixed effect(s), including cltype, math_old, which estimate the overall relationship with math across the entire dataset. For more detailed interpretations of fixed effects, use `details = "fixed"`. #>  #> The model includes the following random effects across grouping variables: cltype | school_id. #>  *The random intercept(s), school_id, account for variations in the intercept across different groups, allowing each group to have its own baseline value that deviates from the overall average. #>  *On top of the varying baselines, the model allows the effects of cltype on math to differ across their corresponding groups. This means that not only can each group start from a different baseline, but the strength and direction of the relationships between these variables and math can also vary from one group to another. #> Check `details = 'random'` for more interpretation.

title: Interpretation and Diagnostics for lme4 Hierarchical Models
text: Conduct likelihood ratio test (LRT) selected fixed random effect fitted lmer model:
code: fix_result <- lrt_lmer(model, target = "math_old", type = "fixed", data = star) #> Likelihood Ratio Test for 'math_old' (fixed effect) #> Full Model: math ~ cltype + math_old + (cltype | school_id) #> Reduced Model: math ~ cltype + (cltype | school_id) #> Test Statistics: #> - Log-Likelihood Difference: 3202.807 #> - Degrees of Freedom: 1 (Difference in estimated parameters) #> - P-Value: < 2.2e-16 (Chi-square test) #> Since p = < 2.2e-16, under alpha level of 0.05, we reject the null hypothesis. The test suggests that the fixed effect of math_old is statistically significant and contributes to the model.  fix_result #> $logLik #> [1] 3202.807 #>  #> $df #> [1] 1 #>  #> $pvalue #> [1] 0

title: Interpretation and Diagnostics for lme4 Hierarchical Models
text: Gain insights within-group heterogeneity core residual plots:
code: library(ggplot2)  res_norm(model) res_fit(model) res_box(model, group_var = "school_id")

title: Interpretation and Diagnostics for lme4 Hierarchical Models
text: Utilize fresh dataset curated specifically mixed-effect modeling:
code: tibble::glimpse(star) #> Rows: 4,192 #> Columns: 13 #> $ school_id <fct> 63, 20, 5, 50, 69, 79, 5, 41, 19, 78, 11, 66, 38, 69, 43, 52… #> $ system_id <fct> 30, 11, 4, 21, 35, 41, 4, 17, 11, 41, 8, 32, 14, 35, 18, 22,… #> $ sctype    <fct> rural, suburban, rural, rural, rural, rural, rural, suburban… #> $ gender    <fct> female, female, female, male, male, male, male, female, fema… #> $ ethnicity <fct> cauc, afam, cauc, cauc, cauc, cauc, cauc, cauc, afam, cauc, … #> $ cltype    <fct> small, regular+aide, regular+aide, regular, regular, small, … #> $ tdegree   <fct> bachelor, bachelor, bachelor, master, bachelor, bachelor, ba… #> $ tyear     <int> 1, 4, 23, 8, 7, 14, 8, 19, 26, 13, 14, 24, 3, 12, 6, 15, 9, … #> $ lunch     <fct> free, non-free, non-free, non-free, non-free, free, free, no… #> $ read_old  <int> 568, 588, 573, 596, 614, 608, 608, 586, 520, 596, 569, 608, … #> $ read      <int> 587, 644, 599, 626, 641, 665, 597, 606, 578, 606, 606, 654, … #> $ math_old  <int> 579, 579, 550, 590, 639, 603, 579, 603, 540, 587, 584, 546, … #> $ math      <int> 593, 639, 583, 618, 684, 648, 589, 631, 606, 667, 596, 606, …

title: Interpretation and Diagnostics for lme4 Hierarchical Models

title: Interpret Linear Mixed-Effects Model — explain_lmer
text: Provides user-friendly interpretation fitted lmer model's fixed random effects.

title: Interpret Linear Mixed-Effects Model — explain_lmer
code: explain_lmer(model, details = "general")

title: Interpret Linear Mixed-Effects Model — explain_lmer
text: model fitted model object lme4::lmer(). Currently supporting formula contains shorthand ., y ~ .. details character specifying details return: "general" (default): high-level summary model structure, fixed effects, random effects brief explanations. "fixed": -depth interpretation fixed effects model context, additional details individual fixed effect estimates. "random": concise interpretation random term (including random intercept slope), insights estimated variance components.

title: Interpret Linear Mixed-Effects Model — explain_lmer
text: character string interpretation model. Additional structured outputs stored attributes can accessed follows: details = "fixed": use attr(, "fixed_details") individual fixed effect interpretation model estimates; use attr(, "fixed_names") fixed effect variable names. details = "random": use attr(, "var_details") insights regarding estimated variance components random effects.

title: Interpret Linear Mixed-Effects Model — explain_lmer
code: library(lme4) #> Loading required package: Matrix model <- lmer(math ~ math_old + cltype + (cltype | school_id), data = star)  # For high-level summary explain_lmer(model) #> This linear mixed-effects model examines how math_old, cltype affects math, while accounting for group-level variability across school_id. #>  #> The model adjusts for fixed effect(s), including math_old, cltype, which estimate the overall relationship with math across the entire dataset. For more detailed interpretations of fixed effects, use `details = "fixed"`. #>  #> The model includes the following random effects across grouping variables: cltype | school_id. #>  *The random intercept(s), school_id, account for variations in the intercept across different groups, allowing each group to have its own baseline value that deviates from the overall average. #>  *On top of the varying baselines, the model allows the effects of cltype on math to differ across their corresponding groups. This means that not only can each group start from a different baseline, but the strength and direction of the relationships between these variables and math can also vary from one group to another. #> Check `details = 'random'` for more interpretation.  # For fixed-effect specific interpretation fix <- explain_lmer(model, "fixed") #> This model includes the following fixed effects: math_old, cltypesmall, cltyperegular+aide, along with the baseline estimate (Intercept). #> Fixed effects estimate the average relationship between the predictors and the response variable `math` across all groups. #> These effects reflect how changes in each predictor influence `math`, assuming all other variables are held constant and deviations from the baseline are measured accordingly. #>  #> To interpret the estimates: #> - The <Estimate> represents the expected change in `math` for a one-unit change in the predictor.  #> - The <Standard Error> reflects uncertainty around the estimate. #> - The <t-value> measures the significance of the effect relative to its variability. #> - The <Correlation> provides insight into the relationships between fixed effect predictors. #>  #>  #> For detailed interpretations of each fixed effect, use: `attr(, 'fixed_details')[['variable_name']]` to view specific results. You can find the list of available fixed effect variable names using: `attr(, 'fixed_names')` to guide your extraction.  # Access individual fixed effect interpretation of model estimats attr(fix, "fixed_details")[["(Intercept)"]] #> [1] "The intercept estimate suggests that when all predictors are set to zero, the expected value of `math` is approximately 201.646. This serves as the baseline for evaluating the effects of other variables in the model."  # For random-effect specific interpretation random <- explain_lmer(model, "random") #> There is 1 random term you fit in the model: #>  #> cltype | school_id: Your model assumes there is across-group heterogeneity in the baseline level of math across school_id (random intercepts), allowing each group to have its own starting point that deviates from the overall average. Additionally, the effects of cltype on math are allowed to vary within each school_id (random slopes), capturing differences in these relationships across groups. #>  #> To explore variance contributions based on the model estimates, use: `attr(, 'var_details')`.  # Access variance component insights attr(random, "var_details") #> $high_var #> [1] "The following terms explain a substantial proportion of the variance: Residual. This suggests that these random effects contribute meaningfully to capturing group-level heterogeneity. Note: The residual variance dominates, suggesting that within-group heterogeneity explains most of the variation. This could indicate a weak random effect structure." #>  #> $low_var #> [1] "The following terms explain a relatively small portion of the variance: NA, school_id - (Intercept). You might reconsider including these terms in your random effect structure if their contributions are negligible." #>

what: lme4u: Interpretation and Diagnostics for 'lme4' Hierarchical Models — lme4u-package
title: lme4u: Interpretation and Diagnostics for 'lme4' Hierarchical Models — lme4u-package
text: Interpret diagnose linear mixed-effects models fitted 'lme4'. Provides tools summarizing model output, visualizing assumptions checks, performing hypothesis tests.

title: lme4u: Interpretation and Diagnostics for 'lme4' Hierarchical Models — lme4u-package
text: Maintainer: Holly Cui hollycui1218@gmail.com

what: Likelihood Ratio Test for Linear Mixed-Effects Model — lrt_lmer
title: Likelihood Ratio Test for Linear Mixed-Effects Model — lrt_lmer
text: Hypothesis testing selected fixed random effect fitted lmer model using Likelihood Ratio Test. Currently support models fitted lme4::lmer() contain fixed effects single random structure (.e., nested /, double vertical ||, multi-level random effects).

title: Likelihood Ratio Test for Linear Mixed-Effects Model — lrt_lmer
code: lrt_lmer(model, target, type, data, has_interaction = FALSE, verbose = TRUE)

title: Likelihood Ratio Test for Linear Mixed-Effects Model — lrt_lmer
text: model fitted model object lme4::lmer(). Currently supporting formula contains shorthand ., y ~ ., one random structure. target character value specifying variable tested. Must match either fixed effect variable within random effect structure. type character string indicating whether target "fixed" "random" effect. data data frame used fit model. has_interaction logical value, TRUE FALSE (default), indicating whether model contains interaction fixed effects. TRUE, terms containing target removed form reduced model. verbose logical value, TRUE (default) FALSE, controlling whether detailed test summary printed console.

title: Likelihood Ratio Test for Linear Mixed-Effects Model — lrt_lmer
text: named list containing key test statistics: logLik: Numeric. log-likelihood difference full reduced model. df: Integer. degrees freedom difference two models, representing number parameters removed. pvalue: Numeric. p-value Chi-square test.

title: Likelihood Ratio Test for Linear Mixed-Effects Model — lrt_lmer
text: hypothesis test evaluates whether selected effect provides meaningful variance explanation linear mixed-effects model: Null hypothesis H0: selected variable valid effect (.e., coefficient 0 fixed effects, variance component 0 random effects) Alternative hypothesis H1: selected variable significantly contributes model variability test , function removes target variable, refits suitable, reduced model without , compares fit full reduced models using Chi-square test based log-likelihood differences calculated degrees freedom (depending target type).

title: Likelihood Ratio Test for Linear Mixed-Effects Model — lrt_lmer
text: reduced model constructed differently based type effect tested: Fixed effect: target fixed variable removed original lmer() formula, model refitted. Random intercept: full model reconstructed modifying original lmer() call retain random intercept (ignoring random slopes). reduced model standard lm() model containing fixed effects, likelihood ratio test follows mixture chi-square distribution p-value computation. Random slope: target variable removed random slope structure. reduced model remains lmer() model, likelihood ratio test follows mixture chi-square distribution p-value computation. lmer() models fitted within function, including input model provided user, refitted REML = FALSE ensure accurate hypothesis testing.

title: Likelihood Ratio Test for Linear Mixed-Effects Model — lrt_lmer
code: library(lme4) model <- lmer(math ~ math_old + cltype + (cltype | school_id), data = star)  # Fixed effect testing fix_result <- lrt_lmer(model, target = "math_old", type = "fixed", data = star) #> Likelihood Ratio Test for 'math_old' (fixed effect) #> Full Model: math ~ math_old + cltype + (cltype | school_id) #> Reduced Model: math ~ cltype + (cltype | school_id) #> Test Statistics: #> - Log-Likelihood Difference: 3202.807 #> - Degrees of Freedom: 1 (Difference in estimated parameters) #> - P-Value: < 2.2e-16 (Chi-square test) #> Since p = < 2.2e-16, under alpha level of 0.05, we reject the null hypothesis. The test suggests that the fixed effect of math_old is statistically significant and contributes to the model.  fix_result #> $logLik #> [1] 3202.807 #>  #> $df #> [1] 1 #>  #> $pvalue #> [1] 0 #>   # Random intercept testing random_result1 <- lrt_lmer(model, target = "school_id", type = "random", data = star) #> Likelihood Ratio Test for 'school_id' (random intercept effect) #> Full Model: math ~ math_old + cltype + (1 | school_id) #> Reduced Model: math ~ math_old + cltype #> Test Statistics: #> - Log-Likelihood Difference: 603.7954 #> - Degrees of Freedom: 1 (Difference in estimated parameters) #> - P-Value: < 2.2e-16 (Chi-square test) #> Since p = < 2.2e-16, under alpha level of 0.05, we reject the null hypothesis. The test suggests that the random intercept effect of school_id is statistically significant and contributes to the model.  # Random slope testing random_result2 <- lrt_lmer(model, target = "cltype", type = "random", data = star) #> Likelihood Ratio Test for 'cltype' (random slope effect) #> Full Model: math ~ math_old + cltype + (cltype | school_id) #> Reduced Model: math ~ math_old + cltype + (1 | school_id) #> Test Statistics: #> - Log-Likelihood Difference: 326.1249 #> - Degrees of Freedom: 5 (Difference in estimated parameters) #> - P-Value: < 2.2e-16 (Chi-square test) #> Since p = < 2.2e-16, under alpha level of 0.05, we reject the null hypothesis. The test suggests that the random slope effect of cltype is statistically significant and contributes to the model.

title: Assumption Checks for Residuals — residuals
text: res_norm(), res_fit(), res_box() provide diagnostic plots check model assumptions within-group level linear mixed-effects models fitted lme4::lmer(). checks applicable valid lmer model structures (shorthand syntax), including complex nested crossed random structure.

title: Assumption Checks for Residuals — residuals
code: res_norm(model)  res_fit(model)  res_box(model, group_var)

title: Assumption Checks for Residuals — residuals
text: model fitted model object lme4::lmer(). Currently supporting formula contains shorthand ., y ~ .. group_var character value specifying name grouping variable. Must valid random intercept model valid variable data used.

title: Assumption Checks for Residuals — residuals
text: ggplot object.

title: Assumption Checks for Residuals — residuals
text: res_norm() generates quantile-quantile (QQ) plot Pearson residuals assess normality within groups. res_fit() plots Pearson residuals fitted values detect funnel shapes mean-variance trends suggest transformation issues. res_box() creates boxplot residuals grouped specified random intercept grouping variable visually inspect heteroscedasticity. plots help detect violations within-group assumptions mixed-effect models (normality, homoscedasticity, independence), central valid inference hierarchical models. -group assumption checks included , due various natures complex random structures.

title: Assumption Checks for Residuals — residuals
code: library(lme4) library(ggplot2)  model <- lmer(math ~ math_old + cltype + (cltype | school_id), data = star)  res_norm(model)  res_fit(model)  res_box(model, "school_id")

title: Student-Teacher Achievement Ratio Data — star
text: cleaned subset Project STAR dataset. processed version focuses third-grade test scores (math reading) includes key variables mixed-effect modeling.

title: Student-Teacher Achievement Ratio Data — star
code: star

title: Student-Teacher Achievement Ratio Data — star
text: data frame 4,192 rows 13 columns: school_id Factor indicating unique school ID. system_id Factor indicating school system ID. sctype Factor indicating school type: "inner-city", "suburban", "rural", "urban". gender Factor indicating student's gender: "female" "male". ethnicity Factor indicating student's ethnicity: "cauc" (Caucasian), "afam" (African-American), "asian" (Asian), "hispanic" (Hispanic), "amindian" (American-Indian), "". cltype Factor indicating student's class type 3rd grade: "small", "regualr", "regular--aide". tdegree Factor indicating highest degree 3rd grade class teacher: "bachelor", "master", "specialist". tyear Integer years teacher's total teaching experience 3rd grade. lunch Factor indicating whether student qualified free lunch 3rd grade: "free" "non-free". read_old Total reading scaled score 2nd grade. read Total reading scaled score 3rd grade. math_old Total math scaled score 2nd grade. math Total math scaled score 3rd grade.

title: Student-Teacher Achievement Ratio Data — star
text: https://search.r-project.org/CRAN/refmans/AER/html/STAR.html

title: Student-Teacher Achievement Ratio Data — star
text: Project STAR large-scale experiment Tennessee (1980s) studying effect class size student test performance. original dataset tracked 7,000 students across 79 schools kindergarten third grade, randomly assigned one three interventions: small class (13 17 students per teacher), regular class (22 25 students per teacher), regular--aide class (22 25 students full-time teacher's aide). test score data analyzed chapter sum scores math reading portion Stanford Achievement Test. processed version focuses student performance third grade, ensuring hierarchical structure students nested within schools. includes subset key variables related student demographics, prior-year (2nd grade) current-year (3rd grade) test scores, class assignment, teacher qualifications, school-level identifiers. students dataset controlled attending school 2nd 3rd grades. dataset structured facilitate mixed-effects modeling, making well-suited evaluating school effects treatment impacts.

title: Student-Teacher Achievement Ratio Data — star
text: Stock, J.H. Watson, M.W. (2007). Introduction Econometrics, 2nd ed. Boston: Addison Wesley. Data sourced AER package.
